passage_text: Psalmen Davids (Psalms of David) is a collection of sacred choral music, settings mostly of psalms in German by Heinrich Schütz, who had studied the Venetian polychoral style with Giovanni Gabrieli. Book 1 was printed in Dresden in 1619 as his Opus 2. It comprises 26 individual settings, which were assigned numbers 22 to 47 in the Schütz-Werke-Verzeichnis (SWV). Most of them use the text of a complete psalm in the translation by Martin Luther.
summary_text: Psalmen Davids, or Psalms of David, is a collection of sacred choral music composed by Heinrich Schütz, primarily based on translations of psalms by Martin Luther. The music was set in German and was heavily influenced by Schütz's study of the Venetian polychoral style under Giovanni Gabrieli. Book 1 of Psalmen Davids, Schütz's Opus 2, was published in Dresden in 1619 and consists of 26 individual settings, numbered 22 to 47 in the Schütz-Werke-Verzeichnis (SWV). These settings are based on complete psalms from the Bible.

passage_text: The Five Chinese Brothers is an American children's book written by Claire Huchet Bishop and illustrated by Kurt Wiese. It was originally published in 1938 by Coward-McCann. The book is a retelling of a Chinese folk tale, "Ten Brothers". Plot. In the Imperial China of the Qing dynasty, there are five brothers who "all looked exactly alike." They each possess a special talent: the first brother can swallow the sea, the second has an unbreakable iron neck, the third can stretch his legs to incredible lengths, the fourth is immune to burning, and the fifth can hold his breath forever. The five live with their mother by the sea.
summary_text: "The Five Chinese Brothers" is an American children's book written by Claire Huchet Bishop and illustrated by Kurt Wiese, first published in 1938 by Coward-McCann. The first brother can swallow the sea, the second has an unbreakable iron neck, the third can stretch his legs to extraordinary lengths, the fourth is immune to burning, and the fifth can hold his breath indefinitely. title_text: What Happens in Aldershot Stays in Aldershot

passage_text: Madinani Department is a department of Kabadougou Region in Denguélé District, Ivory Coast. In 2014, its population was 39,704 and its seat is the settlement of Madinani. The sub-prefectures of the department are Fengolo, Madinani, and N'Goloblasso. History. Madinani Department was created in 2005 as a second-level subdivision via a split-off from Odienné Department. At its creation, it was part of Denguélé Region. In 2011, districts were introduced as new first-level subdivisions of Ivory Coast. summary_text: Madinani Department is a third-level administrative division located in the Kabadougou Region of Denguélé District, Ivory Coast. Established in 2005 as a split-off from Odienné Department, it initially belonged to Denguélé Region. In 2011, districts were introduced as first-level subdivisions, and regions were reorganized and became second-level subdivisions, with all departments becoming third-level subdivisions. As a result, Madinani Department became part of Kabadougou Region in Denguélé District. Its population in 2014 was 39,704, and its seat is the settlement of Madinani. The department is subdivided into three sub-prefectures: Fengolo, Madinani, and N'Goloblasso.

passage_text: The 2019 Indian Open was a professional snooker tournament. It was due to take place between 18 and 22 September 2018 at the Grand Hyatt Kochi Bolgatty in Kochi, India but was postponed due to the 2018 Kerala floods. The rescheduled Indian Open was played in Kochi from 27 February to 3 March 2019. It was the fifteenth ranking event of the 2018/2019 season. Qualifying took place on 15 and 16 August 2018 in Preston, England. John Higgins was the defending champion, having beaten Anthony McGill 5–1 in the 2017 final, but he lost to Matthew Selt in the semi-finals.
summary_text: The 2019 Indian Open, a professional snooker tournament, was initially scheduled to take place from September 18-22, 2018, in Kochi, India, but was postponed due to the 2018 Kerala floods. The qualifying rounds took place on August 15 and 16, 2018, in Preston, England. John Higgins, the defending champion, lost in the semi-finals to Matthew Selt.

The Fuller Covered Bridge is located on the north side of Montgomery village, on Fuller Bridge Road (a continuation of South Richford Road), just north of its junction with Black Falls Road. passage_text: Douglas John Slack (born 5 April 1941) is a former Australian politician. He was the National Party member for Burnett in the Legislative Assembly of Queensland from 1986 to 2001. He served on the Opposition front bench from 1990 to 1995, holding the portfolios of Family Servinces and Aboriginal and Islander Affairs and Treasury (1990–1992) and Environment and Heritage (1992–1996). He was the first member of the family to build a substantial house on the present site of Eaton Hall in Cheshire. Early life and education. The midrash is also known as "Aggadat Tehillim" or "Haggadat Tehillim." In the 12th century, it began to be called "Shocher Tov" due to its opening verse from Proverbs 11:27, "שחר טוב יבקש רצון ודרש רעה תבואנו" which translates to "A good day seeks favor, but a bad man seeks evil."

Jackson wrote the song with Jim McBride. It peaked at #18 on Billboard's Hot Country Tracks chart, breaking a streak of 27 consecutive singles by Jackson that had peaked in the top 10 of that chart. summary_text: "A House with No Curtains" is a song written and recorded by American country music artist Alan Jackson. Released in January 1998 as the sixth single from his album "Everything I Love," the song was initially the B-side to the album's fourth single "There Goes." Co-written with Jim McBride, the song peaked at #18 on Billboard's Hot Country Tracks chart, marking a break in Jackson's streak of 27 consecutive top 10 hits. The song's lyrics depict a couple who remain together despite their unhappiness.

passage_text: Francis William Markall (24 September 1905 – 9 August 1992) was a Roman Catholic Archbishop. Born in Harringay, Markall was ordained as a Catholic priest at the age of 32 in 1937 and migrated to what was then known as Rhodesia, where he was appointed Coadjutor Archbishop of Salisbury (now Harare, Zimbabwe) in 1956. He resigned 20 years later on 31 May 1976 as Archbishop of Salisbury. On 29 April 1956, aged 50, he was appointed Titular Archbishop of Cotyaeum and ordained as such five months later, on 8 September 1956. He died on 9 August 1992, aged 86, as Archbishop Emeritus of Salisbury. He was a Council Father at the Second Vatican Council.
summary_text: Francis William Markall, born on September 24, 1905, in Harringay, served as a Roman Catholic Archbishop. He was ordained as a priest at the age of 32 in 1937 and later migrated to Rhodesia (now Zimbabwe). In 1956, he was appointed Coadjutor Archbishop of Salisbury (now Harare) and was also titled as the Archbishop of Cotyaeum. He served as the Archbishop of Salisbury from 1956 until his resignation in 1976. Markall participated as a Council Father at the Second Vatican Council and passed away on August 9, 1992, at the age of 86, as Archbishop Emeritus of Salisbury.

summary_text: Midrash Tehillim, also known as Midrash Shocher Tov or the Midrash to Psalms, is an aggadic midrash (a collection of Jewish homiletical teachings) that interprets the Book of Psalms. The midrash is also known as "Aggadat Tehillim" or "Haggadat Tehillim." In the 12th century, it began to be called "Shocher Tov" due to its opening verse from Proverbs 11:27, "שחר טוב יבקש רצון ודרש רעה תבואנו" which translates to "A good day seeks favor, but a bad man seeks evil."

The operation was initiated in response to intelligence suggesting the presence of the People's Army of Vietnam (PAVN) 1st Regiment, 2nd Division near Hiệp Đức, at the western end of the Quế Sơn Valley. After the war, Gummo showed no interest in returning to the theater and instead pursued a successful career in business.

summary_text: In 1976, Richard Aitson created documentaries for the Bicentennial Commission focusing on Native American events. He began curating art shows in 1979 at the Squash Blossom Gallery in Aspen, Colorado. Aitson has since curated numerous group shows, including "Winter Camp 2000" at the National Cowboy and Western Heritage Museum in Oklahoma City. He taught Native American literature at Anadarko High School and served as an Adjunct Professor of Art at Bacone College. Aitson took up beadwork out of necessity when he was invited to join the Kiowa Gourd Clan and needed to create his gourd dance regalia.

passage_text: Edward Akufo-Addo (26 June 1906 – 17 July 1979) was a Ghanaian politician and lawyer. He was a member of the "Big Six" leaders of the United Gold Coast Convention (UGCC) and one of the founding fathers of Ghana who engaged in the fight for Ghana's independence. He became the Chief Justice (1966–70), and later President (1970–72), of the Republic of Ghana. He was the father of the current Ghanaian head of state, Nana Addo Akufo-Addo. Early life and education.

Akufo-Addo served as the Chief Justice of Ghana from 1966 to 1970 and later as the President of the Republic of Ghana from 1970 to 1972. He is the father of the current Ghanaian head of state, Nana Addo Akufo-Addo. Details about his early life and education are not provided in the content.

passage_text: John Henry Kyl (May 9, 1919 – December 23, 2002) was an American politician who served as a member of the United States House of Representatives, representing Iowa's 4th congressional district from 1959 to 1965 and again from 1967 to 1973. He was a member of the Republican Party. Early life and education. Kyl was born in Wisner, Nebraska, the son of Johanna (née Boonstra) and Jon George Kyl, both Dutch immigrants. He graduated from Nebraska State Teachers College (Wayne, Nebraska) and the University of Nebraska. Career. Kyl was a teacher at Nebraska State Teachers College from 1940 to 1950.
summary_text: John Henry Kyl was a Republican American politician who served as a representative for Iowa's 4th congressional district from 1959 to 1965 and again from 1967 to 1973. passage_text: Eleanor Crockett Pressly (1918 – May 10, 2003) was an American mathematician and aeronautical engineer in the sounding rocket program at NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center. Early life. Eleanor Crockett Pressly was born in Due West, South Carolina, the only child of Samuel Agnew Pressly and Georgia Crockett Pressly. She earned a bachelor's degree at Erskine College in 1938, and a master's degree in mathematics at Duke University in 1943. Career. During World War II, Pressly taught mathematics to air corps students at Winthrop College and worked at Radio Research Laboratory at Harvard University.
summary_text: Eleanor Crockett Pressly was an American mathematician and aeronautical engineer who worked in NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center's sounding rocket program. Born in Due West, South Carolina in 1918, she was the only child of Samuel Agnew Pressly and Georgia Crockett Pressly. She earned her bachelor's degree from Erskine College in 1938 and her master's degree in mathematics from Duke University in 1943. During World War II, Pressly taught mathematics to air corps students at Winthrop College and worked at the Radio Research Laboratory at Harvard University.

passage_text: Tułowice () is a town in Opole County, Opole Voivodeship, in south-western Poland. It is the seat of Gmina Tułowice. It lies approximately south-west of the regional capital Opole. It is located within the historic region of Upper Silesia. The town has a population of 4,011. History. In the Middle Ages the settlement was under Polish rule, and then it was also part of Bohemia (Czechia), Prussia and Germany. During World War II, the Germans established and operated the E581 forced labour subcamp of the Stalag VIII-B/344 prisoner-of-war camp in the village.
summary_text: Tułowice is a town in Opole County, Opole Voivodeship, south-western Poland. It serves as the administrative seat of Gmina Tułowice and is approximately south-west of Opole, the regional capital. Historically, the region belongs to Upper Silesia. The town has a population of 4,011. Throughout the Middle Ages, Tułowice was under Polish rule, but it also fell under Bohemia (Czechia), Prussia, and Germany. During World War II, the Germans established and operated the E581 forced labor subcamp of the Stalag VIII-B/344 prisoner-of-war camp in the village.

passage_text: James 1 is the first chapter of the Epistle of James in the New Testament of the Christian Bible. The author identifies himself as "James, a servant of God and of the Lord Jesus Christ" and the epistle is traditionally attributed to James the brother of Jesus, written in Jerusalem between 48–61 CE. Alternatively, some scholars argue that it is a pseudographical work written after 61 CE. This chapter contains the letter prescript, an exposition about the joy in temptations, related to three connected actions: hearing, speaking and doing. Text and interpretation.
summary_text: James 1 is the first chapter of the Epistle of James in the New Testament of the Christian Bible. The author, who identifies as "James, a servant of God and of the Lord Jesus Christ," is traditionally believed to be James the brother of Jesus, and the epistle was written in Jerusalem between 48-61 CE. However, some scholars argue that it was written after 61 CE or is a pseudographical work. The chapter discusses the joy in temptations, emphasizing the importance of three connected actions: hearing, speaking, and doing. The text and its interpretation are central to the chapter.
